claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors

claims.caveat: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit, showing the effect is IFN-dependent.

claims.claim: Interferon-associated antigen processing increases, broadening the peptide repertoire on MHC-I and improving tumor visibility to T cells.

evidence.quote: Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: PD-L1 pathway activity increases after mRNA vaccination, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors; PD-L1 upregulation may vary by tumor type.

claims.claim: Combined mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 intervention improves tumor control in mouse models.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy): 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, and tumor-type heterogeneity limits generalization.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in metastatic cancer patients receiving ICI treatment.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely, and vaccination timing varied across patients.
